data.title: REPUTATIONS: Dominion and Discord
data.meta_description: Lieutenant-General Sir Edwin Alfred Hervey Alderson was a popular leader...
data.text:
Lieutenant-General Sir Edwin Alfred Hervey Alderson was a popular leader, but suffered humiliation by being relieved of command. Michael E Haskew unpicks his career

Murder, massacre, flames and fury awaited soldiers in the early spring of 1896 as war erupted again in Rhodesia, the country now known as Zimbabwe. The conflict later dubbed the Second Matabele War would last an agonising 20 months.

Where there is conflict, the professional soldier wants to participate, and such was the case with Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel Edwin Alderson, a 37-year-old veteran who played a significant role in the African fighting and later served as the British general commanding Canadian troops. On receiving word to “hold myself in readiness to proceed to Aldershot in order to go out to South Africa with the Mounted Infantry”, Alderson considered the news “most delightful”. He had served with them on three earlier occasions and was their first adjutant upon official formation in 1888. Alderson soon learned that he was to command four companies of mounted infantry, the Highland, English, Irish and Rifle Companies, bound for Cape Town and onto the Rhodesian interior.

Once in the field, soldiers endured the privations of war…
